answers: Thirty-Three Orientals [or the Treinta y Tres Orientales]
parts: This revolutionary group led by Manuel Oribe and Juan Lavalleja helped win Uruguay’s independence from Brazil. A flag created by this group features three horizontal stripes with the words “freedom or death” on it.

This country’s independence struggle included being part of the Kingdoms of both Guatemala and Mexico. This country was later led by the Sandinistas after the fall of the Somoza dynasty in this country’s capital of Managua.
This country’s independence from Spain and then Colombia was supported by the United States, who later built a canal in this country that connected the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

answers: vitreous humor [or vitreous body; do not accept or prompt on “aqueous humor”]
parts: Name this clear gel in which retinal blood vessels are suspended. Unlike a similarly named substance, this substance cannot be continuously replenished.
The anterior hyaloid membrane separates the vitreous humor from this structure. Along with the cornea, this structure helps focus light onto the retina.
The vitreous humor, along with the lens, cornea, and retina, are part of this sensory organ. This organ contains cone and rod cells and it enables vision.

answers: John Coolidge Adams [do not accept or prompt on “John Luther Adams”]
Richard Milhous Nixon [accept Nixon in China]
parts: Name this composer who based the opera The Death of Klinghoffer on the hijacking of the Achille Lauro. This composer focused on Robert Oppenheimer and the Manhattan Project in Doctor Atomic.

Adams also composed an opera about this president’s visit to China. In the opera, this president, who later resigned in the midst of the Watergate scandal, watches a performance of The Red Detachment of Women.

John Adams won the Pulitzer Prize for music for On The Transmigration of Souls, a piece composed after this event. In the piece, which was commissioned by the New York Philharmonic, several voices read the names of victims of this event.

answers: eternal light [accept flame or lamp in place of light, accept sanctuary lamp, accept synonyms for eternal, prompt on lamp, light, or flame alone]
parts: Name these Jewish houses of worship that often serve as gathering places or community centers for congregations.
Most synagogues contain an ark, where copies of this holy text are kept. Along with the Nevi’im and the Ketuvim, this text makes up the Tanakh.

One of these things, meant to symbolize God’s presence, hangs in front of the Torah Ark in synagogues. This thing, which is called ner tamid in Hebrew, may also allude to the menorah at the Temple in Jerusalem.
Among his 2019 reads, Obama included a box set of works by this late author who wrote about Sethe killing her baby to save her from slavery in her novel Beloved.
Obama’s 2018 list included this author’s novel A House for Mr. Biswas. Another novel by this Trinidadian author takes place in a country led by the “Big Man” and is titled A Bend in the River.
In 2015, Obama read this African-American author’s Between the World and Me. In 2014, this journalist for The Atlantic analyzed housing discrimination in his article “The Case for Reparations”

answers: Jupiter, The Bringer of Jollity [accept either underlined part; prompt on The Planets]
parts: Name this piece, the fourth in a larger suite that also includes movements subtitled “The Winged Messenger” and “The Mystic.”
This composer included Jupiter as part of the astronomically-inspired suite The Planets. This composer set Walt Whitman’s poetry to music in The Mystic Trumpeter.

This then-director of the New York Philharmonic improvised an additional movement titled “Pluto, the Unpredictable” at the end of the last episode of their televised Young People’s Concerts. This composer included the aria “Glitter and Be Gay” in the operetta Candide.

answers: Ganesha [accept Vinayaka or Ganapati; be lenient with vowel stress]
parts: This god, whom Parvati fashioned from clay, had his head cut off by Shiva in a rage. It was then replaced with the head of an elephant, giving this Hindu god of wisdom his most distinctive feature.

When Kama, the god of love, attempted to shoot Shiva with one of his arrows, Shiva incinerated him with this specific body part. In an encounter with Brihaspati and Indra, Shiva used this body part of his to create Jalandhara.

In one aspect, Shiva vanquished Yama, the god of death. As a result, he is sometimes depicted doing this on top of Death. He also performs this action in his aspect Nataraja, which means “Lord of [this action].”

answers: depth [accept depth-first search; prompt on DFS]
parts: Name these branching data structures, named for its resemblance to a type of plant, whose highest and lowest nodes are called roots and leaves. In the “binary” type of these structures, each parent node has at most 2 children.
The AVL tree is more effective in performing this task than a red-black tree, due to it being self-balancing. In order to perform the binary type of this task, a given list must first be sorted.

For a node in a tree, this value is the distance from the node to the root of the tree. A widely-used algorithm to search trees that fully searches each path of a tree and then backtracks, is known as “this value”-first search.

answers: concentration camps [prompt on camps; prompt on internment camps]
Horatio Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener [accept Lord Kitchener]
parts: The Second Boer War was fought primarily in what is now this African country. This country’s policy of Apartheid led it to be isolated from the rest of the world.
Emily Hobhouse exposed the high mortality rate and inhumane treatment at these brutal facilities during the Second Boer War. The Fawcett Commission was established to inspect these locations.

This general imprisoned many Boers in concentration camps during the Second Boer War. This general also fought against Mahdists in Sudan and preceded David Lloyd George as War Secretary during World War 1.
Name this woman whom an author supposedly met on Good Friday in 1327, the dedicatee of much of Il Canzoniere.
This early Renaissance poet and humanist wrote a collection of his namesake style of sonnets about Laura in Il Canzoniere and wrote the collection On Illustrious Men.
Petrarch described this man in Liber I of On Illustrious Men. This Roman politician is assassinated by members of the Senate on the ides of March in a Shakespeare play.

Name this character played by Kelsey Grammer who works as a radio psychiatrist on his namesake 1990s sitcom. On that show, this character frequently responds to his listeners with the catchphrase “I’m listening.”
Frasier Crane first appeared on this earlier show as a patron of the title Boston bar. This show starred Ted Danson as former Red Sox pitcher Sam Malone.
Frasier takes place in this city, which Frasier moves to following the conclusion of Cheers. Frasier’s logo features this city’s skyline, including its iconic Space Needle.

answers: Archaic Greek [accept ancient Greek, accept modern Greek, accept Ελληνικά [ell-inn-ick-uh]]
parts: Identify this nickname frequently given to both the Mexican author and nun Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz and the author of “Ode to Anactoria” and “Ode to Aphrodite” that alludes to their membership in a group of people that also includes Clio and Terpsichore.

This “Tenth Muse” is the author of “Ode to Aphrodite” and the “Ode to Anactoria.” Some poems by this author, whose sexuality is frequently debated, were collected and translated by Anne Carson in If Not, Winter.
Sappho wrote in this language, as did the authors Pindar and Sophocles. The modern version of this language, which Constantin Cavafy used to write “Ithaka” is spoken in cities like Athens.

answers: Republic of Chile [accept República de Chile]
subway system [accept rapid transit, prompt on public transportation]
parts: Name this South American country led by Sebastian Piñera. Water rights have been a growing issue between parties living in this country’s Atacama Desert.

A hike in the fares of these services in Santiago sparked protests in Chile in 2019. Other examples of these services include the Paris Métro and the London Underground, the latter of which is known colloquially as the Tube.

These indigenous people and second-largest ethnic group in Chile have increasingly resisted logging and mining operations on their lands. Pope Francis expressed his support for this group while delivering a mass at their capital, Temuco.

answers: Nuclear Magnetic Resonance spectroscopy [or NMR spectroscopy]
parts: EPR spectroscopy is often used to identify these substances. These highly reactive substances are formed from the homolytic cleavage of a covalent bond, typically by UV radiation.
EPR spectroscopy is analogous to this other type of spectroscopy, which analyzes J-coupling to identify bond lengths and plots data based on its chemical shift.
To slow down reactions for higher precision, samples in EPR spectroscopy are often contained in a liquid form of this element. This element with atomic number 2 is the lightest noble gas.
Name this British economist who advocated the use of government spending to boost the economy in times of recession.

Keynes claimed economic activity was determined by the aggregate form of this quantity. This quantity, which measures the amount of goods consumers are willing and able to purchase, is often contrasted with supply.

Keynes argued that this law, which says that “supply creates its own demand,” is inaccurate. This law, named for a French economist, has been interpreted by some to imply that a general glut cannot occur.

answers: Black Panther Party for Self-Defense [accept Black Panthers]
parts: Name this program that targeted the Communist Party, anti-Vietnam war protesters, and other groups that were deemed “subversive.” William Sullivan led this program, whose existence was revealed after a 1971 break-in at a Pennsylvania office.

COINTELPRO targeted this revolutionary Oakland-based organization, whose members included Fred Hampton and Huey Newton. This organization, which ran the Free Breakfast for Children program, advocated self-defense and gun ownership as part of its leftist, anti-racist ideology.

COINTELPRO was devised by this agency and its longtime leader, J. Edgar Hoover. This agency, which is currently led by Christopher Wray, is responsible for domestic law enforcement on the federal level.

answers: The Third of May, 1808 [or El tres de Mayo, 1808]
The Disasters of War [or Los Desastres de la guerra]
parts: Name this painting that depicts French soldiers about to execute a man during the Peninsular War. This painting’s companion work depicts an uprising in the Puerta del Sol against French Mamluks.
The Third of May, 1808 was inspired by executions that occurred after an uprising in this city. Goya spent much of the period during the Peninsular War in this Spanish capital.

This set of 82 prints by Goya was likely a protest against the Peninsular War. This collection includes a work titled “This is worse,” which depicts a rebel impaled on a tree, and “They do not know the way,” which shows prisoners tied together in a line with a rope.

Name this collection of short stories that ends with Gabriel Conroy watching snow fall on Michael Furey’s grave. It includes “The Dead” and “Ivy Day in the Committee Room” which are set in this collection’s title city.
Dubliners is a collection by this Irish author, who wrote about one day in the life of Leopold Bloom in Ulysses.

This story from Dubliners concerns a boy’s visit to the title Oriental bazaar to buy a gift for Mangan’s sister. His trip doesn’t come to fruition as the girl selling porcelain is too busy flirting with two men.
Name this quantity that represents the work needed to move an electric charge between two points. This scalar quantity is often assumed to be zero far away from a charged source.
The voltage across a resistor is equal to the product of current and resistance by this law. This law’s German namesake also names the SI unit for resistance.
For any circuit component, the amount of this quantity dissipated is given by the voltage difference across the component times the current through it by Joule’s heating law.

answers: tithes [or tithing, accept Church of the Tithes, prompt on taxation, do NOT accept or prompt on “Dormition of the Virgin Mary,” because that is not a practice used to fund the construction of the church]
parts: Identify this capital of Ukraine named for its legendary founder.
In 1240, Kiev was razed by Batu, a grandson of Genghis Khan and founder of this khanate, supposedly named for the color of its tents.

During Batu Khan’s siege of Kiev, a stone church named for this practice was destroyed by the invading forces. The church, which bears the name of this practice, is named after this method, which Vladimir I used to fund the construction of the church.
